p: The antimicrobial activities of the essential oil from P. microphylla were qualitatively and quantitatively assessed by the presence or absence of inhibition zone diameters (IZD) and MIC (Minimum Inhibitory Concentration) values by the microdilution method. The results are presented in Table 3. The inhibition zone diameter of almost 15 mm was indicative of a good antimicrobial activity. Additionally, the corresponding minimum inhibitory concentration (MIC) was equal to 0.512 mg/mL [ 9]. Thus, the essential oil of P. microphylla showed a strong antibacterial activity against the tested Gram-positive and negative bacteria with MIC values of 0.270 mg/mL (IZD: 15.1–15.4 mm) and 0.150–0.480 mg/mL (IZD: 9.0–21.8 mm), respectively. The best activities were observed against E. coli with an MIC value of 0.150 mg/mL (IZD: 21.8 mm) followed by B. subtilis, S. aureus, and P. aeruginosa. However, it did not have a significant activity against the fungus (MIC: >0.5 mg/mL).
